awd_abstract_narration:
This research investigates four fundamental questions in quantum information processing. 
1. The power and limitations of two quantum provers, in particular the relation of this model with the classical complexity classes of Polynomial Space and Exponential Time. 
2. The optimal rate at which mixed state quantum information can be compressed, in particular if a well-known lower bound on the rate by Holevo quantity is tight.  
3. Strong lower bound on quantum one-way communication.  
4. The power and limitations of short quantum refereed games, in particular the relation of those models with other quantum and classical complexity classes.

Quantum information processing is of fundamental importance to the security, prosperity, and welfare of the nation, as it may lead to revolutionary technologies for super-fast computing and secure methods for communication.  The successful completion of this project will illuminate the power and limitations of quantum information processing capabilities, thus contribute to the realistic deployment of quantum information technologies.  PI will actively involve undergraduate and graduate students in his research.

por.por_cntn:
Many exciting applications of quantum information have been discovered in recent decades. In more recent years, steady progresses are being made to turn these theoretical achievements into real world technologies. Through this project, the PI, his students and collaborators strove to discover more applications of quantum information processing with quantifiable quantum advantages. They also sought to understand the limitations of quantum information processing methods, identifying their upper limits as well as the conditions that are necessary for their success.


A wide range of theoretical problems were investigated. These include quantum computation involving multiple parties; quantum communication protocols; secure computation on encrypted quantum data; and quantum cryptographic hashing of a classical message. The major scientific outcomes include limitations on quantum one-way communication protocols; significant advantages of quantum cryptographic hashing against classical leakage; information-theoretically secure quantum homomorphic encryption schemes based on transversal quantum gates; and severe limitations for such schemes when carrying out general quantum computation and for fault-tolerant quantum computation through transversal quantum gates. 

The research activities were integrated with trainings of many individuals. These include 8 undergraduate students, 2 Ph.D. students, and 1 assistant research scientist. Several of them are continuing their research on quantum information science at the next level, and most are embarking on a STEM career.
